<br>*   [Ibrahim Aqil](/wiki/Ibrahim_Aqil "Ibrahim Aqil")<br>    <br><br>Related topics<br><br>*   [Iran–Israel proxy conflict](/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_proxy_conflict "Iran–Israel proxy conflict")<br>    <br>*   [Hezbollah–Israel conflict](/wiki/Hezbollah%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "Hezbollah–Israel conflict") |     |

The **Majdal Shams attack**, took place on 27 July 2024, when a rocket hit a [football pitch](/wiki/Football_pitch "Football pitch")
 in [Majdal Shams](/wiki/Majdal_Shams "Majdal Shams")
 in the [Israeli-occupied](/wiki/Israeli-occupied_territories "Israeli-occupied territories")
 [Golan Heights](/wiki/Golan_Heights "Golan Heights")
.[\[a\]](#cite_note-5)
 The resulting blast killed 12 [Syrian](/wiki/Syrians "Syrians")
 children belonging to the [Druze](/wiki/Druze "Druze")
 community[\[1\]](#cite_note-Picheta-1)
[\[2\]](#cite_note-Bulos-2)
[\[3\]](#cite_note-muddi-3)
 and injured at least 42 others,[\[5\]](#cite_note-TOI27July-6)
[\[6\]](#cite_note-Ynetnews20240727-7)
 with most of the victims being between the ages of 10 and 16.[\[5\]](#cite_note-TOI27July-6)
[\[1\]](#cite_note-Picheta-1)

[Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel")
 blamed [Hezbollah](/wiki/Hezbollah "Hezbollah")
 for carrying out the attack with an Iranian-made [Falaq-1](/wiki/Falaq-1 "Falaq-1")
 rocket equipped with a 53-kilogram warhead.[\[5\]](#cite_note-TOI27July-6)
[\[7\]](#cite_note-AP-8)
 Hezbollah said it had targeted a nearby military base and that the football pitch was hit by an errant Israeli [Iron Dome](/wiki/Iron_Dome "Iron Dome")
 [air defence](/wiki/Air_defence "Air defence")
 projectile. Hezbollah and other Lebanese forces attacked Israel 1,258 times.[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)

Hezbollah employed advanced Iranian-origin missiles, including the [Falaq-1](/wiki/Falaq-1 "Falaq-1")
 rocket system, in its attacks against Israel.[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)
 Following a similar attack in June which injured civilians on a soccer field in the Druze town of [Hurfeish](/wiki/Hurfeish "Hurfeish")
, Israel said it targeted military sites deep within Lebanon in response.[\[19\]](#cite_note-WSJ20240727-20)

Attack
------

Early in the morning, Hezbollah took responsibility for multiple attacks including one with a Falaq-type rocket on the military headquarters of the Hermon Brigade, which was 3 km from the football pitch.[\[5\]](#cite_note-TOI27July-6)
[\[24\]](#cite_note-BBC20240728b-25)
[\[25\]](#cite_note-TheGuardian20240728-26)
 At 6:18 pm, alarms sounded in Majdal Shams.[\[26\]](#cite_note-JPost20240727-27)
 A projectile then hit and exploded at a soccer field in the town, located near a playground. At least 42 others were injured.[\[30\]](#cite_note-TimesOfIsrael20240728-31)
[\[31\]](#cite_note-32)
[\[32\]](#cite_note-33)
 None of the 12 children and teens killed had Israeli citizenship.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Picheta-1)
 Although accepting Israeli citizenship is an option available for Druze in the Golan Heights, at the time of the attack, about 75% of the population of Majdal Shams had rejected Israeli citizenship and identified as Syrian.[\[33\]](#cite_note-34)

### Analysis

The IDF stated that they had performed an assessment and concluded that Hezbollah was responsible for the rocket attack.[\[6\]](#cite_note-Ynetnews20240727-7)
 IDF spokesman [Daniel Hagari](/wiki/Daniel_Hagari "Daniel Hagari")
 stated that the type of rocket used was an Iranian-made Falaq-1,[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)
 carrying a 50 kg [warhead](/wiki/Warhead "Warhead")
, which has previously been used by Hezbollah, the only Iranian proxy to possess it.[\[35\]](#cite_note-ynet28july-36)
 The Israeli army posted pictures of Falaq-1 shrapnel that it said was found at the scene of the attack, but with no apparent pictures of the shrapnel in situ at the blast site.[\[36\]](#cite_note-mscac-37)

A Hezbollah spokesperson, [Mohammad Afif](/wiki/Mohammad_Afif "Mohammad Afif")
, later said that the group was not responsible for the attack on Majdal Shams.[\[6\]](#cite_note-Ynetnews20240727-7)
[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN20240727-28)
[\[9\]](#cite_note-BBC20240728a-10)
[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)
[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)
 instead stating it was caused by an Israeli [Iron Dome](/wiki/Iron_Dome "Iron Dome")
 projectile launched in the course of countering Hezbollah rocket fire aiming for Israeli military sites.[\[25\]](#cite_note-TheGuardian20240728-26)
 Iranian and Qatari state media claimed there were reports that an Iron Dome interceptor was to blame.[\[39\]](#cite_note-40)
[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)
[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)
 Additionally, _[Al-Mayadeen](/wiki/Al-Mayadeen "Al-Mayadeen")
_, a Lebanese outlet with close ties to Hezbollah, stated that the blast site was inconsistent with a Falaq-1, which it said would have left a larger impact crater;[\[36\]](#cite_note-mscac-37)
 subsequent to the report, the Israeli government voted to ban _Al-Mayadeen_ from operating inside Israel.[\[42\]](#cite_note-43)

According to US intelligence, there were no doubts that Hezbollah was responsible but it was not certain if Hezbollah intentionally targeted the site or misfired.[\[29\]](#cite_note-APNews20240728-30)

Israeli authorities have characterized it as the deadliest attack on their civilians since the 7 October attacks.[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN20240727-28)
 [Israeli Police](/wiki/Israel_Police "Israel Police")
 and [Northern District](/wiki/Northern_District_(Israel) "Northern District (Israel)")
 detectives secured the crash site to eliminate any further risk to the public and conducted a search for additional remains.[\[26\]](#cite_note-JPost20240727-27)

Colonel [Avichay Adraee](/wiki/Avichay_Adraee "Avichay Adraee")
, the IDF's Arabic-language spokesman, said the rocket attack was launched by Ali Muhammad Yahya, who is a commander at a rocket launching site in [Chebaa](/wiki/Chebaa "Chebaa")
.[\[43\]](#cite_note-44)
[\[24\]](#cite_note-BBC20240728b-25)
 Daniel Sobelman from [Harvard Kennedy School](/wiki/Harvard_Kennedy_School "Harvard Kennedy School")
 highlighted that the strike was "the most serious in Israel in nine months of fighting between the country and militants in Lebanon."[\[19\]](#cite_note-WSJ20240727-20)
 The _[Associated Press](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated Press")
_ described the civilian death toll as the highest in Israel since Hamas’ [October 7 attack](/wiki/October_7_attack "October 7 attack")
, and that it was unclear what Hezbollah, who made a rare denial of the attack, would have gained from attacking Druze in Golan who see themselves as Syrian citizens, as it would hurt their influence in Lebanon.[\[7\]](#cite_note-AP-8)

The _Associated Press_ reported that rocket sirens sounded less than a minute before the explosion, which left a crater 2 meters wide. [Herzi Halevi](/wiki/Herzi_Halevi "Herzi Halevi")
, at the soccer field in Majdal Shams, meeting with Druze community leader Sheikh [Mowafaq Tarif](/wiki/Mowafaq_Tarif "Mowafaq Tarif")
, local council representatives, and senior IDF officers

The IDF Chief of Staff, Lieutenant General [Herzi Halevi](/wiki/Herzi_Halevi "Herzi Halevi")
, visited Majdal Shams to assess the situation and discuss with Sheikh [Mowafaq Tarif](/wiki/Mowafaq_Tarif "Mowafaq Tarif")
, the leader of the Druze community in Israel.[\[49\]](#cite_note-50)

A spokesman for the Israeli Foreign Ministry said that the situation could be resolved without broader conflict if Hezbollah complied with [United Nations Security Council Resolution 1701](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_1701 "United Nations Security Council Resolution 1701")
, which was intended to end the [2006 Lebanon War](/wiki/2006_Lebanon_War "2006 Lebanon War")
 and required that they withdraw behind the [Litani River](/wiki/Litani_River "Litani River")
.[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)

Over 300,000 [shekels](/wiki/Israeli_new_shekel "Israeli new shekel")
 were raised on Sunday by 2,065 people for families in Majdal Shams who lost children in a rocket attack.[\[51\]](#cite_note-52)
 [Israeli Finance Minister](/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(Israel) "Ministry of Finance (Israel)")
 [Bezalel Smotrich](/wiki/Bezalel_Smotrich "Bezalel Smotrich")
, who came to visit the site of the attack, was berated by local residents who called him a "criminal" and a "murderer".[\[52\]](#cite_note-53)
 Some Druze residents of the Golan Heights called on Israel to take decisive action against Hezbollah.[\[53\]](#cite_note-Maariv20240728-54)
[\[54\]](#cite_note-Ynet20240728-55)
[\[55\]](#cite_note-KAN20240729-56)

### 29 July

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Majdal_Shams_29_July_2024_after_the_attack_28_-_Place_of_the_attack.jpg/250px-Majdal_Shams_29_July_2024_after_the_attack_28_-_Place_of_the_attack.jpg)](/wiki/File:Majdal_Shams_29_July_2024_after_the_attack_28_-_Place_of_the_attack.jpg)

Wreaths left at the site of the attack, 29 July 2024.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Majdal_Shams_29_July_2024_after_the_attack_07_-_Sultan_Al-Atrash_monument.jpg/250px-Majdal_Shams_29_July_2024_after_the_attack_07_-_Sultan_Al-Atrash_monument.jpg)](/wiki/File:Majdal_Shams_29_July_2024_after_the_attack_07_-_Sultan_Al-Atrash_monument.jpg)

A black flag of mourning, as well as the [Druze flag](/wiki/Druze_flag "Druze flag")
, at the monument in Majdal Shams in honor of [Sultan Al-Atrash](/wiki/Sultan_Al-Atrash "Sultan Al-Atrash")
, along with photos of the victims

On 29 July, local residents issued a statement were they rejected any retaliation.[\[56\]](#cite_note-b040-57)

Israeli authorities confirmed the death of 11-year-old Jivara Ibrahim Ibrahim, the 12th victim of the attack. Western sources dismissed this claim, citing expert opinion that the rocket had been fired by Hezbollah or another militant group in Lebanon.[\[7\]](#cite_note-AP-8)
[\[8\]](#cite_note-9)
[\[9\]](#cite_note-BBC20240728a-10)
[\[1\]](#cite_note-Picheta-1)
[\[10\]](#cite_note-11)

Local authorities denied that the children were Israeli,[\[1\]](#cite_note-Picheta-1)
 and local residents protested the attendance of Israeli ministers at the funeral for reasons ranging from opposition to politicization of the tragedy to anger at the Israeli government's perceived neglect of their safety.[\[11\]](#cite_note-aa1-12)
[\[12\]](#cite_note-nh-13)
[\[13\]](#cite_note-14)
[\[14\]](#cite_note-15)
[\[15\]](#cite_note-TimesOfIsrael20240729-16)

The attack occurred amid the [Israel–Hezbollah conflict](/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Hezbollah_conflict_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Israel–Hezbollah conflict (2023–present)")
 that has been ongoing since 8 October 2023, a regular exchange of attacks that began following the outbreak of the [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")
.[\[16\]](#cite_note-17)
[\[17\]](#cite_note-WashingtonPost20240728-18)
 Following the attack, Israel [assassinated](/wiki/Assassination_of_Fuad_Shukr "Assassination of Fuad Shukr")
 Hezbollah commander [Fuad Shukr](/wiki/Fuad_Shukr "Fuad Shukr")
.

Background
----------

### Majdal Shams

Further information on the location: [Occupation of the Golan Heights](/wiki/Israeli_occupation_of_the_Golan_Heights "Israeli occupation of the Golan Heights")
 and [United States recognition](/wiki/United_States_recognition_of_the_Golan_Heights_as_part_of_Israel "United States recognition of the Golan Heights as part of Israel")

[Majdal Shams](/wiki/Majdal_Shams "Majdal Shams")
 is a predominantly [Druze](/wiki/Druze "Druze")
 town in the [Israeli-occupied](/wiki/Israeli_occupation "Israeli occupation")
 [Golan Heights](/wiki/Golan_Heights "Golan Heights")
,[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)
[\[19\]](#cite_note-WSJ20240727-20)
 The [Golan Heights](/wiki/Golan_Heights "Golan Heights")
 are a rocky plateau in the [Levant](/wiki/Levant "Levant")
 region of [Western Asia](/wiki/Western_Asia "Western Asia")
 that was captured by [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel")
 from [Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria")
 in the 1967 [Six-Day War](/wiki/Six-Day_War "Six-Day War")
. A senior MDA paramedic described the scene as one of destruction with victims lying on the grass.[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)
[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN20240727-28)

According to residents, the children were playing soccer during the attack and while the [warning siren](/wiki/Civil_defense_siren#Israel "Civil defense siren")
 activated, it was only a few seconds before the rocket hit the field leaving no time to seek shelter.[\[29\]](#cite_note-APNews20240728-30)

### Victims

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Children%27s_funeral_in_Majdal_Shams.png/250px-Children%27s_funeral_in_Majdal_Shams.png)](/wiki/File:Children%27s_funeral_in_Majdal_Shams.png)

A funeral of the deceased a day after the attack

Twelve children, ranging in age between ten and sixteen years old, were killed in the attack. He described the attack as a brutal act targeting children who were simply playing soccer, stating, "They did not return." Herzog urged the international community to not remain silent against Hezbollah's actions, which he linked to Iranian influence, asserting that Israel would "firmly defend its citizens and its sovereignty."[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN20240727-28)
    *   [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel "Prime Minister of Israel")
         [Benjamin Netanyahu](/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu "Benjamin Netanyahu")
         spoke by telephone with Sheikh Mowafaq Tarif following the attack, expressing his "deep horror" at the killing of "children and innocents". He stated that while the conflict would come at a significant cost, the goal is to decisively defeat Hezbollah and restore peace, and he has directed the Foreign Ministry to prepare a global campaign to support actions in Lebanon.[\[6\]](#cite_note-Ynetnews20240727-7)
        
    *   [Minister of Energy](/wiki/Ministry_of_Energy_(Israel) "Ministry of Energy (Israel)")
         [Eli Cohen](/wiki/Eli_Cohen_(politician,_born_1972) "Eli Cohen (politician, born 1972)")
         said that "Lebanon should burn" after the attack.[\[73\]](#cite_note-74)
        

### Lebanon

*    ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Flag_of_Lebanon.svg/40px-Flag_of_Lebanon.svg.png)[Lebanon](/wiki/Lebanon "Lebanon")
    : The government of Lebanon issued a statement urging "immediate cessation of hostilities on all fronts" and condemned attacks on civilians but did not mention Majdal Shams.[\[29\]](#cite_note-APNews20240728-30)
     Lebanese Druze politician [Wiam Wahhab](/wiki/Wiam_Wahhab "Wiam Wahhab")
     said that Druze "blood is not cheap," and called for an independent investigation into the Majdal Shams massacre.[\[30\]](#cite_note-TimesOfIsrael20240728-31)
    *    ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/InfoboxHez.PNG/40px-InfoboxHez.PNG)[Hezbollah](/wiki/Hezbollah "Hezbollah")
        : Hezbollah said it had carried out nine attacks using rockets and suicide drones against IDF targets including Maaleh Golani in response to Israeli airstrikes but denied Majdal Shams had been targeted.[\[29\]](#cite_note-APNews20240728-30)
        
    *   Druze [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Lebanon "Parliament of Lebanon")
        , [Wael Abu Faour](/wiki/Wael_Abu_Faour "Wael Abu Faour")
         said: "The Israeli occupation state weeps over the children martyrs from the occupied Syrian Golan Heights — this is the height of obscenity and hypocrisy," and "Today, they cry over them to incite discord between them and their Arab and Islamic brethren, while war criminal Netanyahu wants to use the Golan tragedy to overturn any negotiations and continue his aggressive war on the Palestinian people"[\[74\]](#cite_note-q442-75)
         Faour also compared the victims in Majdal Shams to those killed by Israel in the [Gaza Strip](/wiki/Gaza_Strip "Gaza Strip")
        .[\[74\]](#cite_note-q442-75)
        
    *   Druze leader of the [Lebanese Democratic Party](/wiki/Lebanese_Democratic_Party "Lebanese Democratic Party")
        , [Talal Arslan](/wiki/Talal_Arslan "Talal Arslan")
        , said: "The Golan will not fall into the trap of Israel's project to pretend to protect minorities"[\[74\]](#cite_note-q442-75)
        
    *   Ahmad Qabalan, Lebanon's Grand [Ja'fari](/wiki/Ja%27fari_school "Ja'fari school")
         Mufti, said: "To the Druze brothers in Lebanon, Syria, and Palestine: our blood, spirit, and struggle are unified, and so is our enemy. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240728012314/https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/)
     from the original on 28 July 2024."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result is from Wikipedia and discusses the Majdal Shams attack that occurred on July 27, 2024, in the Golan Heights. The attack, a rocket strike on a soccer field, killed 12 Syrian Druze children and injured at least 42 others. <image:10220> is not mentioned in the search result. The article states that Israel blamed Hezbollah for the attack, while Hezbollah denied responsibility, suggesting it was caused by an Israeli Iron Dome projectile.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html): 
Content: "!Residence and paramedics rush to help children moments after a rocket attack hit a soccer field in the Druze town of Majdal Shams in the Israeli-controlled Golan of Heights, on July 27, 2024. <image:11200>

Residence and paramedics rush to help children moments after a rocket attack hit a soccer field in the Druze town of Majdal Shams in the Israeli-controlled Golan of Heights, on July 27, 2024. HASSAN SHAMS / AP

A rocket strike Saturday at a football field killed 12, children and teens, Israeli authorities said, in the deadliest strike on an Israeli target along the country's northern border since the fighting between Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah began. In recent weeks, the exchange of fire along the Lebanon-Israel border has intensified, with Israeli airstrikes and rocket and drone attacks by Hezbollah striking deeper and farther away from the border.

Read more Subscribers only [Rising danger on the border between Lebanon and Israel](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/06/09/rising-danger-on-the-border-between-lebanon-and-israel_6674334_4.html)

Majdal Shams had not been among border communities ordered to evacuate as tensions rose, Israel's military said, without saying why. Israel's military said its air force targeted a Hezbollah arms depot on the border village of Kfar Kila, adding that militants were inside at the time.

Hezbollah said its fighters carried out nine different attacks using rockets and explosive drones against Israeli military posts, the last of which targeted the army command of the Haramoun Brigade in Maaleh Golani with Katyusha rockets. Video showed paramedics rushing stretchers off the football field toward waiting ambulances.

Israel's military said its analysis showed that the rocket was launched from an area north of the village of Chebaa in southern Lebanon.

Israel and Hezbollah trading fire since Oct. On the Israeli side, 44 have been killed, at least 21 of them soldiers.

Read more Subscribers only [In Gaza, a young man with Down's syndrome was killed by an Israeli army dog](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-gaza-a-young-man-with-down-s-syndrome-was-killed-by-an-israeli-army-dog_6701609_4.html)

Le Monde with AP and AFP

Israel blamed Hezbollah for the strike in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, but Hezbollah rushed to deny any role. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned that Hezbollah "will pay a heavy price for this attack, one that it has not paid so far."

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10220> This image shows the youngest victim of the Hezbollah rocket that murdered 12 children playing soccer in Israel on July 27, 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10220>)
web_search("Hezbollah rocket Israel July 27 2024 children soccer")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss a rocket strike on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Golan Heights, on July 27, 2024, which killed 12 children and injured others. The sources, including Wikipedia ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack)), The Times of Israel ([https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/](https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/)), and Le Monde ([https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html)), report that Israel blamed Hezbollah for the attack, while Hezbollah denied responsibility. The Times of Israel article includes images of the aftermath of the attack. <image:11187>, <image:11188>, <image:11189>, <image:11193>, <image:11190>, <image:11191>, <image:11192>, <image:11200>


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence confirms a rocket attack on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Israel, on July 27, 2024, which resulted in the death of children. However, the provided images from the web search do not include the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.

The claim states that the image shows the youngest victim of the attack. Without further information, it is impossible to verify if the image is related to the attack.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```

web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

```

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10220> This image shows the youngest victim of the Hezbollah rocket that murdered 12 children playing soccer in Israel on July 27, 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10220>)
web_search("Hezbollah rocket Israel July 27 2024 children soccer")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss a rocket strike on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Golan Heights, on July 27, 2024, which killed 12 children and injured others. The sources, including Wikipedia ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack)), The Times of Israel ([https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/](https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/)), and Le Monde ([https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html)), report that Israel blamed Hezbollah for the attack, while Hezbollah denied responsibility. The Times of Israel article includes images of the aftermath of the attack. <image:11187>, <image:11188>, <image:11189>, <image:11193>, <image:11190>, <image:11191>, <image:11192>, <image:11200>


## Elaboration
The evidence confirms a rocket attack on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Israel, on July 27, 2024, which resulted in the death of children. However, the provided images from the web search do not include the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.

The claim states that the image shows the youngest victim of the attack. Without further information, it is impossible to verify if the image is related to the attack.


## Actions
```
web_search("Malak baby strawberry sunglasses")
```

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10220> This image shows the youngest victim of the Hezbollah rocket that murdered 12 children playing soccer in Israel on July 27, 2024."

## Actions
```

web_search("Hezbollah rocket Israel July 27 2024 children soccer")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss a rocket strike on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Golan Heights, on July 27, 2024, which killed 12 children and injured others. The sources, including Wikipedia ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack)), The Times of Israel ([https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/](https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/)), and Le Monde ([https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html)), report that Israel blamed Hezbollah for the attack, while Hezbollah denied responsibility. The Times of Israel article includes images of the aftermath of the attack. <image:11187>, <image:11188>, <image:11189>, <image:11193>, <image:11190>, <image:11191>, <image:11192>, <image:11200>


## Elaboration
The evidence confirms a rocket attack on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Israel, on July 27, 2024, which resulted in the death of children. However, the provided images from the web search do not include the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.

The claim states that the image shows the youngest victim of the attack. Without further information, it is impossible to verify if the image is related to the attack.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10220> This image shows the youngest victim of the Hezbollah rocket that murdered 12 children playing soccer in Israel on July 27, 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10220>)
web_search("Hezbollah rocket Israel July 27 2024 children soccer")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss a rocket strike on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Golan Heights, on July 27, 2024, which killed 12 children and injured others. The sources, including Wikipedia ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack)), The Times of Israel ([https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/](https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/)), and Le Monde ([https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html)), report that Israel blamed Hezbollah for the attack, while Hezbollah denied responsibility. The Times of Israel article includes images of the aftermath of the attack. <image:11187>, <image:11188>, <image:11189>, <image:11193>, <image:11190>, <image:11191>, <image:11192>, <image:11200>


## Elaboration
The evidence confirms a rocket attack on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Israel, on July 27, 2024, which resulted in the death of children. However, the provided images from the web search do not include the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.

The claim states that the image shows the youngest victim of the attack. Without further information, it is impossible to verify if the image is related to the attack.


## Actions
```
web_search("Malak baby strawberry sunglasses")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results show baby sunglasses, including strawberry-themed ones, from Lily Babe Boutique ([https://www.lilybabeboutique.com/products/sunglasses-sunglasses](https://www.lilybabeboutique.com/products/sunglasses-sunglasses)) and Etsy ([https://www.etsy.com/market/baby_sunglasses_strawberry](https://www.etsy.com/market/baby_sunglasses_strawberry)). <image:11201>, <image:11219>, <image:11222>, <image:11221> The search results do not contain the image in the claim.


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence does not support the claim. The image in the claim has not been found in any of the search results. The search results show baby sunglasses, including strawberry-themed ones, but none of them match the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10220> This image shows the youngest victim of the Hezbollah rocket that murdered 12 children playing soccer in Israel on July 27, 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10220>)
web_search("Hezbollah rocket Israel July 27 2024 children soccer")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss a rocket strike on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Golan Heights, on July 27, 2024, which killed 12 children and injured others. The sources, including Wikipedia ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack)), The Times of Israel ([https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/](https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/)), and Le Monde ([https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html)), report that Israel blamed Hezbollah for the attack, while Hezbollah denied responsibility. The Times of Israel article includes images of the aftermath of the attack. <image:11187>, <image:11188>, <image:11189>, <image:11193>, <image:11190>, <image:11191>, <image:11192>, <image:11200>


## Elaboration
The evidence confirms a rocket attack on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Israel, on July 27, 2024, which resulted in the death of children. However, the provided images from the web search do not include the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.

The claim states that the image shows the youngest victim of the attack. Without further information, it is impossible to verify if the image is related to the attack.


## Actions
```
web_search("Malak baby strawberry sunglasses")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results show baby sunglasses, including strawberry-themed ones, from Lily Babe Boutique ([https://www.lilybabeboutique.com/products/sunglasses-sunglasses](https://www.lilybabeboutique.com/products/sunglasses-sunglasses)) and Etsy ([https://www.etsy.com/market/baby_sunglasses_strawberry](https://www.etsy.com/market/baby_sunglasses_strawberry)). <image:11201>, <image:11219>, <image:11222>, <image:11221> The search results do not contain the image in the claim.


## Elaboration
The evidence does not support the claim. The image in the claim has not been found in any of the search results. The search results show baby sunglasses, including strawberry-themed ones, but none of them match the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The fact-check confirms a rocket attack on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Israel, on July 27, 2024, which resulted in the death of children. However, the image in the claim has not been found in any of the search results. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified. `not enough information`

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

In-stock items ship within 1–3 business days.

Other items show their processing time in blue on the product page.

[Strawberry Fields Baby Blanket](/products/strawberry-fields-baby-blanket?variant=47592775352615)

Strawberry Fields Baby Blanket
==============================

Sale price  $55.00 Regular price  $82.00

Decrease quantity  Increase quantity Add to cart Added

  This item is a recurring or deferred purchase. The Strawberry Fields baby blanket is crafted from 100% minky polyester and features red ripe strawberries tossed onto a lovely cream background.

Dimensions: 32" x 36"

Material: 100% minky polyester

Care Instructions: 

*   Machine wash cold
*   Do NOT use fabric softener, detergent pods, or bleach.
*   Hang to dry or use lowest setting on your dryer with No heat.

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10220> This image shows the youngest victim of the Hezbollah rocket that murdered 12 children playing soccer in Israel on July 27, 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10220>)
web_search("Hezbollah rocket Israel July 27 2024 children soccer")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss a rocket strike on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Golan Heights, on July 27, 2024, which killed 12 children and injured others. The sources, including Wikipedia ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majdal_Shams_attack)), The Times of Israel ([https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/](https://www.timesofisrael.com/11-killed-mostly-children-dozens-more-hurt-as-rocket-hits-soccer-field-in-majdal-shams/)), and Le Monde ([https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/27/in-israel-a-rocket-strike-at-a-soccer-field-killed-at-least-11-children-and-teens_6701822_4.html)), report that Israel blamed Hezbollah for the attack, while Hezbollah denied responsibility. The Times of Israel article includes images of the aftermath of the attack. <image:11187>, <image:11188>, <image:11189>, <image:11193>, <image:11190>, <image:11191>, <image:11192>, <image:11200>


## Elaboration
The evidence confirms a rocket attack on a soccer field in Majdal Shams, Israel, on July 27, 2024, which resulted in the death of children. However, the provided images from the web search do not include the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.

The claim states that the image shows the youngest victim of the attack. Without further information, it is impossible to verify if the image is related to the attack.


## Actions
```
web_search("Malak baby strawberry sunglasses")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results show baby sunglasses, including strawberry-themed ones, from Lily Babe Boutique ([https://www.lilybabeboutique.com/products/sunglasses-sunglasses](https://www.lilybabeboutique.com/products/sunglasses-sunglasses)) and Etsy ([https://www.etsy.com/market/baby_sunglasses_strawberry](https://www.etsy.com/market/baby_sunglasses_strawberry)). <image:11201>, <image:11219>, <image:11222>, <image:11221> The search results do not contain the image in the claim.


## Elaboration
The evidence does not support the claim. The image in the claim has not been found in any of the search results. The search results show baby sunglasses, including strawberry-themed ones, but none of them match the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.

* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10220> This image shows the youngest victim of the Hezbollah rocket that murdered 12 children playing soccer in Israel on July 27, 2024."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10220>)
web_search("Hezbollah rocket Israel July 27 2024 children soccer")
```

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

## Claim

```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results show baby sunglasses, including strawberry-themed ones, from Lily Babe Boutique ([https://www.lilybabeboutique.com/products/sunglasses-sunglasses](https://www.lilybabeboutique.com/products/sunglasses-sunglasses)) and Etsy ([https://www.etsy.com/market/baby_sunglasses_strawberry](https://www.etsy.com/market/baby_sunglasses_strawberry)). <image:11201>, <image:11219>, <image:11222>, <image:11221> The search results do not contain the image in the claim.


## Elaboration
The evidence does not support the claim. The image in the claim has not been found in any of the search results. The search results show baby sunglasses, including strawberry-themed ones, but none of them match the image in the claim. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.


## Actions
```
web_search("Malak baby strawberry field")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results include a baby carrier and a baby blanket with a strawberry field theme. The baby carrier is from Little Zen One ([https://www.littlezenone.com/products/happy-baby-original-baby-carrier-strawberry-fields-black?srsltid=AfmBOorofgIu2Q9VIwXHgG3YKtgCGZVSX_hQpQmmpL_HnvUO-bNqO7VM](https://www.littlezenone.com/products/happy-baby-original-baby-carrier-strawberry-fields-black?srsltid=AfmBOorofgIu2Q9VIwXHgG3YKtgCGZVSX_hQpQmmpL_HnvUO-bNqO7VM)) and the baby blanket is from Dreamy Blankets ([https://dreamyblankets.com/products/strawberry-fields-baby-blanket?srsltid=AfmBOopyNu7kYlBH7KwjbSPrdDT5GJJ0eqbPZktyBYAB0-gIM6htQpwo](https://dreamyblankets.com/products/strawberry-fields-baby-blanket?srsltid=AfmBOopyNu7kYlBH7KwjbSPrdDT5GJJ0eqbPZktyBYAB0-gIM6htQpwo)). The search results do not contain the image in the claim.


## Elaboration
The claim cannot be verified. The image in the claim has not been found in any of the search results. The search results show baby products with a strawberry field theme, but none of them match the image in the claim.


## Final Judgement
The claim is not supported by the evidence. While there was a rocket attack on a soccer field in Israel on July 27, 2024, the image provided in the claim does not appear to be related to the event. The image has not been found in any of the search results. `false`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is unverified. While there was a rocket attack on a soccer field in Israel on July 27, 2024, the image provided in the claim does not appear to be related to the event. The image has not been found in any of the search results.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In June 1936, Columbia University expelled student activist Robert Burke for leading an anti-Nazi demonstration."

# Your Actions



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
```
web_search("Columbia University Robert Burke expelled June 1936")
```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In June 1936, Columbia University expelled student activist Robert Burke for leading an anti-Nazi demonstration."

## Actions
```
web_search("Columbia University Robert Burke expelled June 1936")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student_activism_at_Columbia_University): 
Content: "Police were called, [Master of Arts](/wiki/Master_of_Arts "Master of Arts")
 degrees were not awarded, and the valedictory address was not given.

1936 protest against Nazis
--------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Student_activism_at_Columbia_University&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: 1936 protest against Nazis")\
\]

In 1936, Robert Burke of the [Columbia College](/wiki/Columbia_College,_Columbia_University "Columbia College, Columbia University")
 class of 1938 led a rally outside President [Nicholas Murray Butler](/wiki/Nicholas_Murray_Butler "Nicholas Murray Butler")
's mansion to protest Columbia's friendly relationship with the [Nazis](/wiki/Nazis "Nazis")
.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)
 Burke was expelled and was never readmitted. The agreement was signed at a ceremony on board the [USS _Iwo Jima_](/wiki/USS_Iwo_Jima_(LHD-7) "USS Iwo Jima (LHD-7)")
, docked in New York for the Navy's annual Fleet Week.[\[28\]](#cite_note-28)

Divestment from private prisons
-------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Student_activism_at_Columbia_University&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Divestment from private prisons")\
\]

In February 2014, after learning that the university had over $10 million invested in the private prison industry, a group of students delivered a letter President Bollinger's office requesting a meeting and officially launching the Columbia Prison Divest (CPD) campaign.[\[29\]](#cite_note-29)
 As of June 30, 2013[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Student_activism_at_Columbia_University&action=edit)
, Columbia held investments in [Corrections Corporation of America](/wiki/CoreCivic "CoreCivic")
, the largest private prison company in the United States, as well as [G4S](/wiki/G4S "G4S")
, the largest multinational security firm in the world. Students demanded that the university divest these holdings from the industry and instate a ban on future investments in the private prison industry.[\[30\]](#cite_note-The_New_Divestment_Movement2-30)
 Aligning themselves with the growing [Black Lives Matter](/wiki/Black_Lives_Matter "Black Lives Matter")
 movement and in conversation with the heightened attention on race and the system of [mass incarceration](/wiki/Mass_incarceration "Mass incarceration")
, CPD student activists hosted events to raise awareness of the issue and worked to involve large numbers of members of the Columbia and West Harlem community in campaign activities.[\[30\]](#cite_note-The_New_Divestment_Movement2-30)
 After eighteen months of student driven organizing, the Board of Trustees of Columbia University voted to support the petition for divestment from private prison companies, which was confirmed to student leaders on June 22, 2015.[\[31\]](#cite_note-auto2-31)
 The Columbia Prison Divest campaign was the first campaign to successfully get a U.S. Wien Stadium")<br>    <br>*   [Levien Gymnasium](/wiki/Levien_Gymnasium "Levien Gymnasium")<br>    <br>*   [Robertson Field at Satow Stadium](/wiki/Robertson_Field_at_Satow_Stadium "Robertson Field at Satow Stadium") |

Search

Student activism at Columbia University

[](#)
[](#)
[](#)
[](#)
[](#)
[](#)
[](#)
[](#)

1 language [Add topic](#) [Jump to content](#bodyContent)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

[Columbia University](/wiki/Columbia_University "Columbia University")
 in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City")
, [New York](/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)")
, has seen numerous instances of student protests, particularly beginning in the late 20th century.

1811 Riotous Commencement
-------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Student_activism_at_Columbia_University&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: 1811 Riotous Commencement")\
\]

The 1811 commencement was cancelled midway through its proceedings after graduating senior John B. He went on to lead 80,000 workers in the 1937 [Little Steel Strike](/wiki/Little_Steel_Strike "Little Steel Strike")
.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)
 As of 2018[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Student_activism_at_Columbia_University&action=edit)
, the university has not apologized for expelling him.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

Protests of 1968
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Student_activism_at_Columbia_University&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Protests of 1968")\
\]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Hamilton_statue_at_Columbia_University_IMG_0958.JPG/250px-Hamilton_statue_at_Columbia_University_IMG_0958.JPG)](/wiki/File:Hamilton_statue_at_Columbia_University_IMG_0958.JPG)

[Hamilton Hall](/wiki/Hamilton_Hall_(Columbia_University) "Hamilton Hall (Columbia University)")
 was occupied by protesting students in 1968

Main article: [Columbia University protests of 1968](/wiki/Columbia_University_protests_of_1968 "Columbia University protests of 1968")

Students initiated a major demonstration in 1968 over two main issues. Students barricaded themselves inside [Low Library](/wiki/Low_Memorial_Library "Low Memorial Library")
, [Hamilton Hall](/wiki/Hamilton_Hall_(Columbia_University) "Hamilton Hall (Columbia University)")
, and several other university buildings during the protests, and New York City police were called onto the campus to arrest or forcibly remove the students.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)
[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

The protests achieved two of their stated goals. A popular myth states that the gym's plans were eventually used by [Princeton University](/wiki/Princeton_University "Princeton University")
 for the expansion of its athletic facilities, but as [Jadwin Gymnasium](/wiki/Jadwin_Gymnasium "Jadwin Gymnasium")
 was already 50% complete by 1966 (when the Columbia gym was announced) this was clearly not correct.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)
 At least 30 Columbia students were suspended by the administration as a result of the protests. The protests hurt Columbia financially as many potential students chose to attend other universities and some alumni refused to donate money to the school.

Protests against racism and apartheid
-------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Student_activism_at_Columbia_University&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Protests against racism and apartheid")\
\]

Further student protests, including hunger strike and more barricades of [Hamilton Hall](/wiki/Hamilton_Hall_(Columbia_University) "Hamilton Hall (Columbia University)")
 and the Business School during the late 1970s and early 1980s, were aimed at convincing the university trustees to divest all of the university's investments in companies that were seen as active or tacit supporters of the [apartheid](/wiki/History_of_South_Africa_in_the_apartheid_era "History of South Africa in the apartheid era")
 regime in South Africa.[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)
 A notable upsurge in the protests occurred in 1978, when following a celebration of the tenth anniversary of the student uprising in 1968, students marched and rallied in protest of university investments in South Africa."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Wikipedia article "Student activism at Columbia University" states that in 1936, Robert Burke led a rally to protest Columbia's relationship with the Nazis and was expelled.

_________________________

**When Columbia University Expelled Robert Burke for Anti-Nazi Protests in 1936**
=================================================================================

[![Shari Rose](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*AoLrVOh21vRxouzuQUM6wQ.png)](/@blurredbylines?source=post_page---byline--d9f236c91794---------------------------------------)

[Shari Rose](/@blurredbylines?source=post_page---byline--d9f236c91794---------------------------------------)

6 min read

_“The Dismissal of Bob Burke. This became our major point of difference.”

Burke said he warned Dean Hawkes that his [expulsion would have a chilling effect on student speech](https://archive.org/details/TheDismissalOfBobBurke.HeidelbergComesToColumbia/mode/2up)
 at Columbia: “I told the Dean that if I were expelled it would appear to the student body that this action was an attempt to frighten the ASU out of any action of significance and to frighten politically conscious students so that they would not take part in ASU affairs.”

(…)

**Read the full story at** [**https://blurredbylines.com/articles/robert-burke-columbia-university-expulsion-1936-protest/**](https://blurredbylines.com/articles/robert-burke-columbia-university-expulsion-1936-protest/)

SEO consultant & owner of Blurred Bylines. (_[_Source_](https://archive.org/details/TheDismissalOfBobBurke.HeidelbergComesToColumbia/mode/2up)
_)_

Soon after Robert Burke led an anti-Nazi protest at Columbia in 1936, he was expelled. In 2025, history repeats itself over and over.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Robert Burke was a junior at Columbia University who dared to protest the administration’s ties to Nazi Germany in 1936. Butler never spoke with them](https://archive.org/details/TheDismissalOfBobBurke.HeidelbergComesToColumbia/mode/2up)
 again.

So, Columbia students made their divestment demands known through a nonviolent protest at his home.

Robert Burke Leads Anti-Nazi Protest at Columbia President’s House
------------------------------------------------------------------

Before Robert Burke was expelled from Columbia University, he was the president-elect of his junior class and a leading member of the America Student Union at the university. Heidelberg Comes to Columbia” is a 20-page document from the ACLU and other organizations that details the events at Columbia University that led up to Burke’s expulsion and its aftermath in 1936. While Oxford, Cambridge and others [rejected the invitation](https://archive.org/details/TheDismissalOfBobBurke.HeidelbergComesToColumbia/mode/2up)
 and hoped their absence would serve as a “condemnation of Nazi attacks upon academic freedom,” Columbia University agreed to attend, setting the stage for anti-fascist protests on its campus.

Columbia Accepts Invitation to Heidelberg University
----------------------------------------------------

Columbia Assistant Secretary Philip Hayden announced on February 28, 1936 that the administration would send a representative to Heidelberg because “it is the custom of Columbia University to be represented, whenever conveniently possible, at all celebrations of educational institutions here and abroad.”

_Writer’s note: Made in collaboration with the American Civil Liberties Union, the American Student Union chapter at Columbia and the Burke Defense Committee, a 20-page document called “_[_The Dismissal of Bob Burke. Student journalists [argued that the university’s presence](https://spectatorarchive.library.columbia.edu/?a=d&d=cs19360302-01.2.12&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN-------)
 “will in effect be bestowing a benediction upon the spoliation of education and culture by the Hitler regime.”

They continued: “\[Columbia\] will be giving its approval to those who have suppressed academic freedom, perverted the content and teaching of all branches of learning, fostered a fraudulent ‘race science,’ dismissed and persecuted scholars on religious, political and racial grounds.”

Soon after Hayden’s announcement, the American Student Union (ASU) chapter voted to oppose the university’s participation and organized demonstrations against it. The article reads: “Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels and other Nazi functionaries will be among the most prominent hosts to scholars and scientists who have been invited to represent the universities of the world.”

In other words, it had become clear to students that this engagement with Heidelberg University was not simply an academic courtesy, but rather a tacit endorsement of the Nazi takeover of universities and colleges.

Nearly 45 days after President Butler promised to meet with students and reconsider the invitation, [Philip Hayden told the student committee](https://archive.org/details/TheDismissalOfBobBurke.HeidelbergComesToColumbia/mode/2up)
 that “Dr. Butler has nothing to see the committee about.”

In response to the administration’s stonewalling, Robert Burke led a group of 300 students onto South Field on the evening of May 12, 1936."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Medium article "When Columbia University Expelled Robert Burke for Anti-Nazi Protests in 1936" by Shari Rose, published on March 20, 2025, discusses the expulsion of Robert Burke from Columbia University in 1936 for leading anti-Nazi protests. The article mentions that Burke was expelled soon after leading an anti-Nazi protest. It also references a 20-page document detailing the events leading up to Burke's expulsion. The article states that Burke led a group of 300 students onto South Field on the evening of May 12, 1936.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

## Claim
Claim: "In June 1936, Columbia University expelled student activist Robert Burke for leading an anti-Nazi demonstration."

# Search Result
From [Source](https://blurredbylines.com/articles/robert-burke-columbia-university-expulsion-1936-protest/): 
Content: "Butler’s house and I again apologized for the two questionable matters, making it clear that I had not used profanity nor left the picket signs.”

In a short letter sent from Dean Hawkes himself, Robert Burke was expelled from Columbia University on June 16, 1936.

### **Burke Fights for Reinstatement to Columbia University**

In “[The Dismissal of Bob Burke](https://archive.org/details/TheDismissalOfBobBurke.HeidelbergComesToColumbia/mode/2up)
,” collaborators with the ASU, ACLU and Burke Defense Committee come to the conclusion that the student’s removal is “clearly an attack on the right of student organization and action.”

The piece continues: “Burke’s expulsion is an attempt to stifle student opinion. Please consider giving, especially in light of [Trump’s desire to ethnically cleanse](https://www.cnn.com/2025/01/27/middleeast/trump-clean-out-gaza-middle-east-intl/index.html)
 Gaza.**

 again.

So, Columbia students made their divestment demands known through a nonviolent protest at his home.

### **Robert Burke Leads Anti-Nazi Protest at Columbia President’s House**

Before Robert Burke was expelled from Columbia University, he was the president-elect of his junior class and a leading member of the America Student Union at the university. Heidelberg Comes to Columbia” is a 20-page document from the ACLU and other organizations that details the events at Columbia University that led up to Burke’s expulsion and its aftermath in 1936. today.

### **The Rise of Nazism on University Campuses in 1930s**

Soon after Adolf Hitler rose to power, Germany’s Civil Service Law was enacted in April 1933. While Oxford, Cambridge and others [rejected the invitation](https://archive.org/details/TheDismissalOfBobBurke.HeidelbergComesToColumbia/mode/2up)
 and hoped their absence would serve as a “condemnation of Nazi attacks upon academic freedom,” Columbia University agreed to attend, setting the stage for anti-fascist protests on its campus.

### **Columbia Accepts Invitation to Heidelberg University**

Columbia Assistant Secretary Philip Hayden announced on February 28, 1936 that the administration would send a representative to Heidelberg because “it is the custom of Columbia University to be represented, whenever conveniently possible, at all celebrations of educational institutions here and abroad.”

_Writer’s note: Made in collaboration with the American Civil Liberties Union, the American Student Union chapter at Columbia and the Burke Defense Committee, a 20-page document called “_[_The Dismissal of Bob Burke. This, to me, was loyalty to Columbia,” Burke wrote.

_The New York Times covers Burke’s short return to Columbia University in September 1936."

* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim

According to the Wikipedia article "Student activism at Columbia University" ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student_activism_at_Columbia_University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student_activism_at_Columbia_University)), Burke led a rally to protest Columbia's relationship with the Nazis.

The Medium article "When Columbia University Expelled Robert Burke for Anti-Nazi Protests in 1936" ([https://medium.com/@blurredbylines/when-columbia-university-expelled-robert-burke-for-anti-nazi-protests-in-1936-d9f236c91794](https://medium.com/@blurredbylines/when-columbia-university-expelled-robert-burke-for-anti-nazi-protests-in-1936-d9f236c91794)) and the Blurred Bylines article ([https://blurredbylines.com/articles/robert-burke-columbia-university-expulsion-1936-protest/](https://blurredbylines.com/articles/robert-burke-columbia-university-expulsion-1936-protest/)) also discuss Burke's expulsion. DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In June 1936, Columbia University expelled student activist Robert Burke for leading an anti-Nazi demonstration."

## Actions
```
web_search("Columbia University Robert Burke expelled June 1936")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
In 1936, Robert Burke was expelled from Columbia University for leading an anti-Nazi protest. According to the Wikipedia article "Student activism at Columbia University" ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student_activism_at_Columbia_University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student_activism_at_Columbia_University)), Burke led a rally to protest Columbia's relationship with the Nazis.

The Medium article "When Columbia University Expelled Robert Burke for Anti-Nazi Protests in 1936" ([https://medium.com/@blurredbylines/when-columbia-university-expelled-robert-burke-for-anti-nazi-protests-in-1936-d9f236c91794](https://medium.com/@blurredbylines/when-columbia-university-expelled-robert-burke-for-anti-nazi-protests-in-1936-d9f236c91794)) and the Blurred Bylines article ([https://blurredbylines.com/articles/robert-burke-columbia-university-expulsion-1936-protest/](https://blurredbylines.com/articles/robert-burke-columbia-university-expulsion-1936-protest/)) also discuss Burke's expulsion. The Blurred Bylines article states that Burke was expelled on June 16, 1936, after leading an anti-Nazi protest (<image:11245>, <image:11249>).


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence confirms the claim. Robert Burke was expelled from Columbia University in June 1936 for leading an anti-Nazi protest. The Blurred Bylines article specifies the date of expulsion as June 16, 1936.
